moves.1... d5 2. Nf3 c5 3. c4 Nf6 4. cxd5 cxd4: Here interesting is  6...Nc7!? The continuation 7.Bf4 Nd7 8.Bc4 e5 9.Qb3 Qf6 10.Bg3  leads to a complicated game.
moves.7. Nc3 e5: ?! If 7...a6 8.e5 Nd5  9.e6 and Black stands worse. The right move here is 7...e6.
moves.10. Nd6+ Bxd6 11. Qxd6 Qe7 12. Qxe7+ Nxe: Better was to keep the bishop; e.g., 17.Rac1 Ne6  18.Nd5, etc.
moves.17... Rxc5 18. Rac1 Nc6: A mistake. Black should play  18...Rc7 followed by ...O-O.
moves.19... Rxd5: If 19...Rc4  20.b3 Rd4 21.Ke3 f6 22.Na4 Ke7 23.Nc5 Rxd5 (23...Rb8 24.Nxb7)  24.exd5 Nb4 25.d6%2B with advantage for White.
moves.22... f6 23. fxe5 fxe5 24. Ke4 Kd6 25. R: Also strong was 28.b3 and White  will win at least a pawn; for example, 28...Nb5 29.Nxb5! Rxb5  30.Rxg7 h5 31.Rh7 Rxd5%2B 32.Ke3.
moves.33... Rxa2 34. Rh7+ Kd8 35. d6 Nb5: The threat was Nf6 and Rh8%2B mate.
Rubinstein conducted the endgame of this  game with monumental mastery.
